executive_summary: Non-hotel casinos have struggled over the past five years, mainly because of an influx of new casino hotels in states that have eased restrictions on casinos. Increased competition has placed pressure on profit, and the outbreak of COVID-19 forced many casinos to close temporarily, resulting in revenue plummeting an estimated 22.1% in 2020 alone. Tourism trends significantly affect casino revenue because consumers tend to spend their income on gambling while on vacation or a weekend getaway. Rising domestic travel benefited the industry until 2020 when the effects of COVID-19 paused travel for many consumers. In 2021, as regulations eased and more of the general public became vaccinated, consumers flocked to industry establishments, resulting in a sharp uptick in revenue. Revenue has not yet returned to pre-pandemic levels.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Increased Competition Has Eaten Into Industry Profit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Existing casinos struggle to stay afloat because of increased competition from casinos with lodging accommodations attached, lotteries, Native American Casinos and online casinos. As unemployment rose and consumer confidence fell in 2020, demand for services weakened since consumers didn't have the funds for discretionary spending like gambling. Casinos have had to contend with changing consumer preferences as young people flock to other forms of entertainment, like live music and online games. Online casinos and sportsbooks have captured a significant portion of this demographic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: States Bet On Casinos To Boost Tax Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Casinos have become an increasingly popular way for cash-strapped states to raise funds. These establishments offer gambling opportunities, attracting both local residents and tourists, thereby boosting economic activity and providing a source of income through taxes and licensing fees. The non-hotel casino industry in the US has grown at a CAGR of 1.5% to $22.7 billion over the past five years, including a 1.0% increase in 2024. Inflation and volatility have hindered revenue growth slightly towards the end of the period. The industry will benefit from an improving economy and a growing social acceptance of gambling. Gambling has become an established part of US culture, and most Americans now view casino gambling as acceptable. Still, the industry will continue to face increasing pressure from new casino hotels as states look to casino operations to boost tax revenue. Consumers' demand for more interactive forms of entertainment, like live shows and concerts, will also threaten the industry. Industry revenue will increase at a CAGR of 1.3% to $24.2 billion over the next five years.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Mixed Economic Conditions Create A Rocky Road
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Domestic trips by US residents, inbound trips by non-US residents and consumer spending will have a period of growth, benefiting casinos. Inflation, volatility, and effects from the COVID-19 pandemic will slightly hinder revenue growth. A higher rate of discretionary spending, coupled with increased travel, leads to a larger customer base and more spending at casinos. Some states where casino gambling is illegal may introduce commercial casinos to boost taxes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A Growing Number Of Gamblers Are Gambling Closer To Home
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: New casinos will open because of changes in state-based legislation legalizing their operations. New sports betting may benefit the industry, but it may also cause increased cannibalization if states rapidly open up new casinos. The rise in popularity of online sportsbooks will also threaten casinos with greater competition. Since sports betting has traditionally been prevalent online, its legalization may drive many individuals to bet at home, decreasing foot traffic in casinos.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Rising Competition Puts Downward Pressure On The Revenue Of Existing Casinos
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will need to catch up to growth in profit as rising competition puts downward pressure on the revenue of existing casinos, forcing casinos to spend more on marketing and promotions. Younger gamblers prefer more interactive table games, increasing the employment of dealers and floor staff per location. Making sure to offer a wide range of entertainment options, like live music performances or themed events, will be essential.

industry_definition: This industry consists of gambling facilities that offer table wagering games and other gambling activities, like slot machines and sports betting. These establishments often provide food and beverage services. The industry also includes floating casinos (i.e., gambling cruises and riverboat casinos). Not included in this industry are Lotteries and Native American casinos (IBISWorld report 71329) and casinos that operate in conjunction with a hotel (IBISWorld report 72112).

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Gambling Fees and Taxes are a Cost of Doing Business in the Industry
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Other costs have risen since 2019. US states that allow casinos always charge license fees and taxes based on measurements like the percentage of gross revenue earned and the number of gaming and table games operated. State tax revenue from gambling will increase as more states legalize sports betting.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages are a High Cost for Casinos
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wage costs have fallen in 2024 as many casinos were forced to downsize following the pandemic. Wage costs can vary depending on industry establishments' size and types of services. Many staff members may have higher wages if the services require personnel with specialized skills and training. Wages will decline as a share of revenue as casinos add more gaming machines and other technologies to reduce some labor costs.
